question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
True or false (explain your answer): If \emph{v} is an eigenvector for
the invertible matrix \emph{A}, then \emph{v} is also an eigenvector for
the matrix \emph{A}\textsuperscript{â1}.
sols:
\textbf{Step 1.} If \emph{v} is an eigenvector for a matrix \emph{A} for
some eigenvalue λ, then we can write

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
Av = \lambda v\end{align*}

\textbf{Step 2.} Since we assume that the matrix \emph{A} is invertible,
we can multiply on the above equation by that inverse on the left on
each side and obtain

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
A^{-1}Av = A^{-1}\lambda v\end{align*} Which is equivalent to

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
v = \lambda A^{-1} v\end{align*}

\textbf{Step 3.} We would now like to divide by λ, but before we should
check that this is allowed, i.e. that λ is not zero. Since \emph{A} in
invertible, \emph{Aw = 0 = 0(w)} implies \emph{w = 0}. Thus λ = 0 is
\textbf{not} an eigenvalue for \emph{A} and we can safely bring λ to the
LHS in the equation above. This yields

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\frac{1}{\lambda}v = A^{-1} v\end{align*} which would mean that \emph{v} is an
eigenvector for the eigenvalue 1/λ of the inverse of the matrix
\emph{A}. So we can conclude that the statement is \textbf{true}.
hints:
